Award.AwardTitle: Sustainable Interdisciplinary Research to Inspire Undergraduate Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
There have been recent urgent calls to train more students for the 21st Century scientific workforce and to increase the diversity of students entering Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) careers. Many studies illustrate the positive influence of research experiences on the performance, retention, attitudes and career decisions of undergraduate science majors In this project Sacramento State, a large comprehensive urban 4-year university with a diverse student body, aims to increase undergraduate student success by building a STEM Education Community that engages Biological Sciences faculty and students, campus science educators and community partners in interdisciplinary research on a problem of particular interest to them and of general importance to the entire nation; human impact on the ecology of rivers, in this case the American River flowing at the college's doorstep.

The project's teaching approach is built around the tenants of Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action. Its emphasis is on community building within the university to ensure that all biology students experience the intellectual stimulation of a research project and that faculty learning communities be established to ensure ongoing institutional commitment to a quality undergraduate education for all students. The primary mechanism employed is development and implementation of research-based classroom experiences in which students at all levels of training explore a single large-scale problem. The project involves the biology department, in cooperation with educational researchers, in science education research, extensive curriculum development, faculty development and interdisciplinary program development. Twelve biology courses will be transformed by this project. Fourteen tenured faculty will participate in a Faculty Learning Community in order to implement evidence-based teaching practices, effective use of technology in the classroom and to collaborate across their sub-disciplines in multiple courses to solve big scientific problems. Integrating a range of inputs, the team will iteratively improve the modules using a design-based research and development strategy. Among the broader impacts of this course is that it is sustainable and scalable and easily adapted by other institutions because it utilizes existing course budgets and places no undue pressure on individual faculty laboratory finances.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate of Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Sustainable Interdisciplinary Research to Inspire Undergraduate Success (SIRIUS) project addressed national calls for institutions of higher education to provide more authentic experiences for undergraduate science students. The project further addressed a biology department’s challenges to provide undergraduate research experiences for a larger, more diverse population of students.

The project had the following specific aims:

SPECIFIC AIM 1.  Develop a strong faculty learning community focused on integrating scientific expertise with the science of teaching and learning.

SPECIFIC AIM 2. Develop and integrate authentic research experiences, centered around the biological impacts of human activity on the American River, into twelve existing undergraduate laboratory courses.

To address the first specific aim, we developed and supported a faculty learning community (FLC) in which faculty worked collaboratively to design and coordinate Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) or CURE modules in 12 existing biology courses. Although not part of the original proposal, faculty from chemistry, geology and environmental sciences also participated in the FLC. This led to cross-disciplinary collaboration and the expansion of CUREs to six additional science courses. In total, 38 faculty participated in the FLC activities. This far exceed our goal of engaging 16 faculty from the Biological Sciences, and faculty overwhelmingly reported high satisfaction with the FLC activities and valued the time and space to collaborate with colleagues.

To address the second specific aim, we implemented CUREs or CURE modules in 16 courses and formally assessed student outcomes in 10 of the redesigned biology laboratory courses. The CUREs were designed with research experiences that explored the human impacts on the American River, an important water resource that runs adjacent to our campus and has been listed as impaired since the early 1970s. At the end of five years, over 5,000 students from approximately 40 disciplines had engaged in at least one SIRIUS CURE, and most biology majors completed four to eight of the courses. Results from key assessments are promising. As students progressed through the SIRIUS curricula from introductory to intermediate to advanced biology CUREs, analyses revealed gains in laboratory self-efficacy, increased understanding of the authentic nature of the laboratory work and an enhanced interest in science/research careers. Results from interviews with 25 biology majors nearing graduation indicated that all possessed an awareness of the SIRIUS project, could articulate the overarching goals and viewed the work as personally and scientifically important.

The SIRIUS Project can serve as a model for faculty professional development, using a multi-year FLC design. It further contributes new knowledge about the impacts on science students who engage in multiple, coordinated CUREs designed around a common, socially-relevant problem or theme.
